Description: Glazed composition large amuletic pendant representing a bird, possibly a vulture (?); depicted as flat based with outspread wings, with feet stretched out in front, now broken off, indicated by two flat rectangular shapes on base; relatively well detailed with fine incisions; feathers on back shown as diamond pattern square blocks, while tail and wings have longitudinal blocks; greenish blue glaze in general, with apple green on base and round neck; secondary black/brown colour on chest; head and feet missing and suspension loop broken off behind head; all edges abraded.
Curator's comments: Petrie published a similar example as 'Flying Vulture' and dated it to the 26th Dynasty (?) (Petrie 1914, pl. XLII, no. 249; identical example in University College, Petrie Collection, P2). Petrie, W.M.F. 1914, Amulets, London.
For a parallel, see London, Petrie Museum, UC79258.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.268) (phase 3)
